content: How can I help you today?

I'm not really sure where to start. Things have just been so stressful at home, and it feels like everything is falling apart. My wife and I are constantly arguing, my son's behavior is out of control, and I can barely focus at work. Honestly, I don't even know if this is going to help, but I'm here because my wife pushed me to come.

Thank you for sharing all of that, especially when things feel overwhelming right now. It sounds like you're facing a lot of challenges and may be feeling pressure from different directions—at home, with your son, at work, and even the push to come here today. Where do you think it would be best to start talking?

I guess I feel like the root of it all is with my son. His behavior has been so challenging, and no matter what we try, it doesn’t seem to help. My wife and I don’t always see eye to eye on how to handle it, and it’s created a lot of strain between us. It’s like I’m constantly on edge at home.

It sounds like your son's behavior has been a big source of stress for you, which has also been affecting your relationship with your wife and your overall peace at home. It must be really difficult to navigate all of this, especially when you’re trying your best, but things still feel tense and unresolved. What do you think has been the hardest part for you in managing your son’s behavior?

I think the hardest part is feeling so helpless. No matter what we do, it doesn’t seem to make a difference, and that’s frustrating. I just want to be able to help him, but I don’t even know where to start anymore.

Feeling helpless when you want so badly to make things better can be really discouraging. It sounds like you've been putting in effort, trying different approaches, but the lack of progress has left you feeling stuck and unsure of what to do next. What do you think your son needs most right now, and what matters most to you in helping him?

I honestly don't know what he needs most. He’s angry all the time, gets upset over the smallest things, and doesn’t listen to us anymore. I just want him to be happy and okay, but I feel like I’m failing him as a dad because I can’t figure out how to help. That’s what matters most—making sure he’s okay. But I don’t even know where to start.

It sounds like your son’s anger and unhappiness are really weighing on your heart, and as a dad, you’re carrying this deep sense of responsibility to support him and help him find peace. Feeling like you’re failing when you care so much must be incredibly tough. What have you already tried to help your son, and is there anything you feel has worked even a little?

We’ve tried everything we can think of—talking to him, setting up rules and consequences, even giving him space—but nothing seems to stick. Sometimes he’ll calm down, but it never lasts long. It’s like we’re always walking on eggshells, and I have no idea what will help him in the long run. It’s exhausting.

It sounds like you've been putting a lot of effort into trying different strategies, but the constant feeling of walking on eggshells and seeing only temporary results is draining for you. All of this work shows how much you care about helping your son, even when things feel so uncertain. What do you think makes him upset or angry the most, and how does it affect you when he reacts this way?

I think he gets frustrated because he feels misunderstood or like things aren’t going his way. It’s hard to tell sometimes because he doesn’t open up. When he starts acting out, I either get angry or shut down completely, and then I feel guilty afterward because it’s not helping him or anyone else. It’s just a cycle I can’t seem to break.

It sounds like both of you are caught in a cycle where frustration builds but neither of you feels truly heard or understood. Your concern for him and the guilt you carry demonstrate how much you’re trying to do right by him, even when the situation feels overwhelming. How would you like for things to be different between you and your son moving forward?

I just want to be able to understand him and what he’s going through so I can actually help him. I want us to have a good relationship where he feels safe to talk to me and doesn’t feel like he has to act out to get attention. I want my reactions to be calmer and better for him, but honestly, I’m so stressed that I don’t even know if I can manage that right now.

You clearly want the best for your son, and the desire for a closer, understanding, and supportive relationship between you is deeply important to you. At the same time, it sounds like the stress you’re carrying is leaving you unsure of whether you can respond the way you wish to. What do you think could help you feel less overwhelmed so you can take steps toward the relationship you’re hoping for?

It sounds like you're carrying so much on your shoulders, and it's hard to pour from an empty cup. Maybe finding a way to take some time for yourself or even just to decompress could help you feel a little more grounded. Have you had any moments where you've been able to manage some of the stress, even briefly?

It sounds like taking care of yourself even in small ways might help you feel more grounded in the midst of the stress you’re managing. Would you like to talk about ways to make space for yourself, or is there another area you’d prefer to explore further?

Honestly, I can’t really think of any moments where I really felt like I managed the stress. It’s been constant, and I feel like I don’t even know how to take a step back or make space for myself without feeling guilty. It’s hard to even imagine what that looks like right now.

You’re working so hard to be there for your family, and carrying that weight non-stop without a break sounds exhausting. Feeling guilty about stepping back makes it even harder to find ways to recharge. Would it be helpful to explore what even small moments of relief could look like for you, or would you rather focus on another piece of what’s going on?

It's clear you're carrying a heavy load right now, and it's tough to even think about caring for yourself when so much feels like it's falling apart at home. That guilt can make it hard to take the time you might need to recharge. Would you be open to exploring some manageable ways to prioritize your well-being or other ways to find support for you and your family?

It still sounds like so much responsibility and stress is on your shoulders, and the idea of stepping back for yourself feels daunting. If you'd like, we could look at some small, realistic ways to prioritize your well-being or explore how you and your family might find additional support together. Or, we could continue focusing on another aspect that's been weighing on you. What feels most helpful to talk about right now?
